item.title: Go forth with courtesy, curiosity, and comedy
item.description:
Not me, not mine, sharing stories of prosocial inter gender socializations in the gym. There are many stigmas of how people dress, why they film themselves, when it's ok to go up to someone, when it's unwelcome. Courtesy, curiosity, comedy.
Anticipating some common gym comments below: athletes record themselves to review form, send to coaches, track progress, affirm themselves. Some, like Georgie, are sponsored athletes that promote their supporters, and promote their own brand for modelling fitwear or coaching. Rule 1 fellas: dont be a creep. Rule 2 fellas: rule 1 is added to every other rule.
item.dc:creator: theSoulciologist

“Wherever you come near the human race there's layers and layers of nonsense.” - Thornton Wilder So, I made a discord server. It's a relaxed environment where you can take/donate memes to the cause, play trivia twice a week, chat about lots of topics or about nothing at all. We also have Jack Box game night and are setting up movie night! Very laid back/relaxed vibe. Come hang with us. https://discord.gg/AWFV7FT3RQ I'm also on the imgcat server for updates & fun: https://discord.gg/TpjD37jgJ9 ***Also if you miss abbiistabbii's discord community good news! Here's the new one https://discord.gg/NPStJGgARq - where everyone's reconnecting, shitposting, and hanging out again*** https://ko-fi.com/mememuseumcurator Unable to work, zero income. Feel free to leave me a tip. Those that have, y'all are the bee's knees. You've honestly been my lifeline. ***Tag me if you see an artist/creator you like whose work isn't getting seen as much as it should be! Or if you are an artist/creator and want me to post something of yours, DM me

item.title: I PAINTED OLIVIA RODRIGO!
item.description: I just finished painting perhaps one of my most ambitious paintings yet. Inspired by Frank Cowper's 1907 painting “Vanity” and the Pre-Raphaelite art overall, it's a painting that I would say perfectly summarizes my graduation thesis at the fine arts academy: The Phantom of Romanticism - How Romanticism Returns in Post-modernism The subject of the painting is @oliviarodrigo and the idea of the painting is to indeed, as my thesis suggests, unite the art of Romanticism, which for those who don't know was an art movement born 17th century Europe, and the contemporary style of the 21st century. I decided not to write and extremely long paragraph here to explain every detail and hidden symbol in this painting because I don't think anyone got time to read something so long so I'll leave you in this video to the process of the painting and the reveal accompanied by some beautiful music and I will post another video in the upcoming days of me explaining every part of this painting. I hope you all like it as much as I do and hopefully more. It took me about 2 months to paint but I think it was really worth the effort.
item.dc:creator: AnisJerbi

item.title: Kindness can be returned tenfold
item.description: Im a district manager for a chain of gas stations and manage 4 stores. One of the stores is in a bad neighborhood in an area with a lot of homeless people. One of the homeless people is an ex-marine named Robert who comes in multiple times a day to buy beer or use the bathroom. He lives behind the store. We let him live there because he keeps the troublemakers away. We are kind of in his territory and we give him food like free hot dogs and coffee and in exchange he keeps away the panhandlers and the homeless people who like to shoplift away. Today my employees psychotic abusive came in while drunk and accuses me of sleeping with his wife because we like to talk and make jokes. I told him id call the police if he didnt leave. He was not happy about this and tried to rush the counter and attack me behind the register. Robert was in the store and saw what happened he tackled the guy and put him in a chokehold and told him he'd kill him if he ever saw him back at the store again. No one has seen the asshole at the store since. Good riddance. I bought him a new camp stove from Amazon as thanks.

item.title: Pam Bondi firing the ethics director, the professional responsibility director, and the inspector general is the exact plot of a mob movie, not how a functioning democracy works.
item.description: So let me get this straight: you get busted for fraud, you hire the Attorney General's brother, and your federal charges just go 'poof'? That's not a legal defense; that's a premium subscription service to corruption. The absolute shamelessness of this administration is staggering. Source: Former DOJ Pardon Attorney on YouTube https://youtube.com/@lawyer_oyer

item.title: We had this credible warning about TRUMP.
item.description: Mary Trump, psychologist, author, and political commentator. She is the niece of Donald Trump who wrote this book warning us about him. The book provides an insider view of Trump family dynamics and reveals details about financial dealings, including the author's work as the anonymous source who revealed her uncle's suspected tax fraud. The Trump family launched a lawsuit in an attempt to stop its publication but was unsuccessful in delaying the release of the book. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Too_Much_and_Never_Enough
item.dc:creator: LunaAtlas

item.title: World cuisine for the UK
item.description: This one sure blew up! Food is a universal language, be it lacking or not?. Some folks over there have mentioned that their "comfort food" is bland because of decades of shortages. How long ago was that, though? 1930s to 1960? If it was comfort food, why hasn't anyone mentioned the post-war staple of SPAM. Oh, right. That's a Yank product. With the exception of Fish & Chips, most of the high cuisine of British kitchens appears to be fine dining or special meals like Sunday dinner or holiday fare. In the US, home cooking comes in many different styles. Many meals I grew up with were quick foods. Hamburgers and sloppy Joe's. While the pasta was store bought, Mom made her sauce frome scratch for spaghetti ?.

item.title: I've explored the abandoned "Spaceship" (International Congress Center) in Berlin, Germany (OC)
item.description:
This monstrosity is part of the ICC, the International Congress Center. It has been abandoned for over a decade now and lies dormant in the heart of the German capital. I've had the opportunity to take a peek inside - come join me on a journey to explore this absolutely unique piece of architecture.
It was abandoned in 2014, mainly due to fears it might be contaminated with asbestos, which was true but later found not to be as severe. Let's start with the little tour of the outskirts.
The building itself is so massive that it's impossible to capture its entirety in one shot from ground level. It's well over 300 m (~1000 ft) long and roughly 90 m (300 ft) wide.
A large overpass connects the ICC to the still active part of the Berlin exposition site ("Messe").
The public part features brutalist 70's vibe. Kinda like the retro-modern charme, but it certainly is not pretty, nor a place you'd feel very comfortable traversing late at night.
But luckily you don't have to, as the "Messe" has its own facilities, such as parking, public transport stops and so on. Despite the ICC being inactive for many years, the remaining part of the area is still very frequently used.
Despite the many entrances, there is usually no getting in. Luckily, the City of Berlin organized an event, allowing a small number of people to apply for a time window to explore the insides. With quite a bit of effort I managed to get one.
Up-close, the architectural style gets even more sci-fi-y. With a slight touch of CGI, this would pass as a thruster of a spaceship for sure.
Let's see if they allow us on board, shall we? We head on in through the main entrance.
Tickets haven't been sold here on a regular basis for way over 10 years. It's a good thing we already have ours.
"Herzlich willkommen im ICC Berlin" it says. Thank you! We appreciate the hospitality :).
The lobby features a scale model of the complex, which is very useful to get a better understanding of it. The building is just too big to be seen in total from ground level, thus the miniature version helps a lot.
This is the cloakroom where you would hand in your coat while being inside. There are literally hundreds of small cabinets. I'm imagining dozens of people worked here and it was really busy for them during big events.
The ICC featured interactive information kiosks. Back in the day, this must have felt mindblowingly modern. It's unfortunate it wasn't working - I would have loved to play around with it.
Oh well. In this case we need to get info from the dedicated desk, where volunteers do a great job providing insights.
The directory is as confusing as the layout of the building itself. While it does provide some hints on what's where, it is of no immediate help in terms of orientation.
A much better indicator is this plan, depicting evacuation routes in cases of emergencies. We'll stick to the edges first and then work our way towards the center.
Of course, as we're in Germany, we need to acquaint ourselves with the "house rules" first. Pretty standard stuff, but this gives us a good indicator when there was still enough activity for them to bother updating them. This dates back to January 2008.
We start our little tour by admiring this incredible retro-modern lighting concept!
The nickname "spaceship" is not only due to the exterior. The hallways could serve as the set for a Star Trek movie, too, with very little alteration. Actual Hollywood productions took place here, too. Some of Aeon Flux with Charlize Theron was filmed here, as were parts of The Hunger Games (Part 2).
The centerpiece of the building is "Großer Saal 1" (large hall), which contains up to 5000 seats. Each one is featuring its own little desk, lamp and handphone jack for live translation and/or dedicated media audio.
Very impressive, especially for the 70s and 80s, was the screen. It had a size of almost 23 m (~75 ft) diagonally ... and a sound system to go along with that.
The tech was controlled partly from the hall itself with small control centers like this one. Mainly that happened from the central control room above the hall, though.
Speaking about the tech. Due to different modernizations across fours decades, the state widely varies. In some cases, it's comparatively new. Here, it's featuring fiber uplinks, which I suppose were used for intra-switch communication.
There are also a few racks with still some networking tech in them. In this case it's a Cisco Cataly WS-C2950-12 ethernet switch with 100 Mbit/s ports, dating back to the early 2000s. Also there's fiber and an ethernet uplink to Deutsche Telekom, Germany's largest ISP.
The security control room is a bit more ... err, shall we say rustic? This looks like the bridge of a space ship from a 60s sci-fi movie.
Love how the escalators connect the intertwining floors. Doesn't make it much easier to navigate, but it sure looks cool.
I'm not sure if the green tiles were contemporary, which would date at least back to the 70s, or if they were deliberately retro even back then. Given that the state of the rest of this bar is relatively modern, I'd guess the latter.
The smaller rooms were used for meetings and small conferences in multiple languages.
They featured small booths for interpreters and the necessary tech for translation. The booths were separated by language.
The second big hall ("Großer Saal 2") is a bit smaller than the first one, but still pretty huge. It features up to 3.000 seats.
"Up to" because both halls were highly configurable. Whole segments of the seating could be moved up to the ceiling with those huge orange chains, depending on the needs of the individual event.
The projectors are mighty, but very likely not original. This seems to be a temporary setup to show media to the guests of the open house.
Even though it is a bit dwarfed by the setup in hall 1, the stage and the screen are still pretty huge.
These young padawans are practicing their lightsaber skills, adding to the sci-fi theme =).
Below the bleachers, we can catch a glimpse of the ventilation system, which made sure each seat was well-tempered.
Also part of the event are several art exhibitions. This one revolves around ... seating, I guess?
Another one has a bit of a clearer meaning. It is part of a campaign to strengthen the preservation of historical monuments, such as the ICC. "Mehr Wert" is a play on words in German, meaning both "added value" as well as indicating that something is "worth more" in relation to something else, in this case "as you think".
The art-centerpiece however belongs to the ICC itself. It is a 3 m (~10 ft) large light sculpture, indicating networking and communication. It it situated right above the central meeting spot, where people from all over the world come together. Really a nice piece of art ... could appear in Cyberpunk.
Another of the "smaller" presentation halls. Love the control room architecture here. If that doesn't scream "Empire" I don't know what is.
We make our way to the roof of the biulding, right in front of what would probably be the bridge of the star cruiser.
If you didn't get one of the rare time slots, they also offered the chance to gain entry by doing maintenance chores such as removing weeds here. "Kehrenbürger" is a pun, combining the German word "kehren" (to sweep) with "Ehrenbürger" (honorary citizen).
You can nicely see another one of Berlins many fascinating lost places from the rooftop terrace - the Teufelsberg. This is a former CIA listening post from the Cold War era, which I incidentally explored quite a few years ago.
Even more interesting though, it gives you an amazing panoramic view of the city center. Seriously, this is about as Berlin-y as it gets. The panorama features the Siegessäule, the Reichstag building, the iconic TV tower, the Berlin Dome, the Red Town Hall and much more!
Although we could only explore for a few short hours, the experience was well worth it! The ICC is truly a unique piece of architecture and Berlin history. The city is planning on deciding its future in summer 2026. As it is very uncertain what will happen to it, I am very glad that I got to see it in its original state and that "I was here!". +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ I explored the abandoned International Congress Center (ICC) in Berlin, Gemany. I did so with the permission of the owner and the authorities. All pictures were taken with either a Canon 80D or a Samsung S22+ and are original content. DISCLAIMER: Exploring sites like this one might be trespassing and thus is most likely illegal if done unauthorizedly. Also, it might be rather dangerous, since there is damage and decay. If you're interested in seeing more morbid, decaying goodness, please consider checking out my other posts: - Abandoned Nazi/Soviet air base in Eastern Germany (OC): https://imgur.com/gallery/i-explored-abandoned-nazi-soviet-air-base-eastern-germany-oc-qsrKjN9 - Various abandoned places on the Island of Tenerife (Canaries): https://imgur.com/gallery/i-explored-various-abandoned-places-on-island-of-tenerife-canaries-spain-oc-F4Jnrt6 - Semi-Abandoned Town of Bombay Beach, Salton Sea, California (OC): https://imgur.com/gallery/i-explored-semi-abandoned-town-of-bombay-beach-salton-sea-ca-sandy-shores-from-gta-v-oc-byp2wws - Abandoned Lake Dolores Waterpark in the Mojave Desert, California (OC): https://imgur.com/gallery/7llNW3M - Abandoned George Air Force Base in Victorville, California (OC): https://imgur.com/gallery/8H0uAao - Abandoned HQ bunker of the Ministery of the Interior of the GDR: https://imgur.com/gallery/6wIRqnC - Abandoned "Sophienheilstätte" sanatorium in Thuringia, Germany: https://imgur.com/gallery/aQyPZkQ - Abandoned Hotel "Schwarzeck" in Thuringia, Germany: https://imgur.com/gallery/p9K55dg - Abandoned Luxury Hotel Fürstenhof in Eisenach, Germany: https://imgur.com/gallery/q2qdGpd - Abandoned Petrova Gora Spomenik in Croatia: https://imgur.com/gallery/QEXrm - Abandoned luxury hotel "Belvedere" near Dubrovnik: https://imgur.com/gallery/SYbeQ - Abandoned hotel "Jadran" in Jelsa on the island Hvar: https://imgur.com/gallery/6peUy

item.title: One mind changed.
item.description: I wiped along a window top and a jumping spider fell onto my hand. A few years ago I would've immediately freaked out, but I didn't thanks to @stonedlikeicheckedoutmedusa changing my mind on spiders. instead I noticed the little spider seemed confused, moving an inch in one direction, then an inch back. I walked over to the grass, put my hand down, and it immediately walked over and onto the grass. Hopefully it's well-fed now that it's in a better area.
item.dc:creator: OatmealChocolateChipCookies

item.title: Just watched his Famous last words on Netflix... Onions are being cut, but what a man, what a legend. His final last words should be listened to, and heard, by everyone. We all could learn from him.
item.description: Editing to add.... This amazing man, Eric Dane, had ALS, he raised a lot of awareness for ALS... He also, most importantly, wanted the above message to be heard loud and clear. He wanted his final words to be heard after his death, and that's why I shared it... I didn't mention the ALS in the title, because tbh I wasn't thinking about that, I was focused on his message... This post and the show is about what he wanted to say, about what he wanted people to hear after his passing.... So I guess I focused on that. Apologies for not making the title more detailed
item.dc:creator: DumpingSh1tandBeingKind2

item.title: WHOLESOME Sunday Dump Of Nice Things To Warm Your Heart #311
item.description:
1. He's always been cool
2. Building a tiny treadmill for a tiny hamster
3. Scratchies disable dog
4. Mlem
5. Wingman
6
7. Awwww
8. Damn that is exquisite
9. Happy doggo
10. Husband surprises bride by flying her parents for the wedding
11. You, you... you stop scrolling and listen for this lady for a sec
12
13
14. I need to find that store
15. Here is what my winter looks like. Show me yours! P.S. As a last post I wanted to share that I'm a game dev and I live in Eastern Europe. We have a history with authoritarianism and it's... downsides. I mean just look at how unintentionally oppressive our architecture looks. So I'm making a game inspired by the Stanley Milgram book Obedience to Authority. I guess the subject has always interested me: "Why do good people follow evil orders?" The game tests if you obey orders and how does your moral compass work (if at all). I invite you to check it out on Steam and maybe wishlist: https://store.steampowered.com/app/2719670/The_Milgram_Experiment P.S. 2 We avoid Gen A.I. because fuck AI anti social world destroying creeps. All voices are of real voice actors, no AI art, no AI writing the script for me!
item.dc:creator: TheseusGames
